dek: Lisa Limer captures the hippest scene in London in this gallery of photos and exclusive outtakes from "London Goes Electric" by Kate Maxwell. Locations include the Boundary Hotel, Brick Lane, and the Broadway Market.
hed: A Photo Tour of London's Stylish East End

items.caption: Shoreditch, once a down-at-heels neighborhood, has become a sizzling center of London’s new wave. Near this cobbled corner is a flower market founded in 1869 by a friend of Charles Dickens’s.
East London abounds in street art, like this pastiche of a holy icon
Be careful where you tread: Insanely small artworks are a hazard in some of the more creatively endowed neighborhoods.
Like other world cities, London is becoming even more multicultural. But East London, long an entry point for immigrants, remains the most exotic at street level.

The foodie fave **Jones Dairy**, just one of many attractions for grazing gourmets. The choices in the neighborhood range from traditional cockney street food like eel pie to chorizo sausages from Spain.
Breakfast awaits at **[Shoreditch House](http://www.shoreditchhouse.com/)**, a club and hotel on the top three floors of a renovated warehouse (and where the roof includes a garden and lawn).
There’s a retro sixties touch to the deep chairs at reception at **[Shoreditch House](http://www.shoreditchhouse.com/)**.

items.title: 6. Kate MacGarry
items.caption: **[Kate MacGarry](http://www.katemacgarry.com/)** is the must-visit in Shoreditch (27 Old Nichol St.; 20-7613-0515).
The neighborhood's artistry can extend to patisseries with what might be called “still life with tarts.”

**The Commercial Tavern**, a spruced-up pub and a magnet for young (and thirsty) style-makers, is in Spitalfields, which has a gruesome association: Jack the Ripper once stalked the alleys. Those so disposed can take special Ripper tours.




 




_Model's clothing all by Burberry Prorsum_

At the southern end of East London, the skyline takes a sudden leap, propelled by the riches of the financial district. Norman Foster’s tapering cylinder, affectionately known as the Gherkin, stands out among the bland towers.

On a balmy summer evening, the rooftop bar at the **[Boundary Hotel](http://theboundary.co.uk/)** in Shoreditch is the place for a sundowner. Like many of the new hot spots, the Boundary was converted from a Victorian warehouse.

The **[Printers & Stationers](http://www.printersandstationers.co.uk/)** café (alluding to the trades that once flourished here) is now a meeting place for visitors to the adjacent Columbia Road flower market on Sundays.

**[Pizza East](http://www.pizzaeast.com/)**, on Shoreditch High Street, pleases current tastes, but in the cockney past, street food often came from the River Thames—including oysters and eels, served in pies or [jellied](/cities/london/my-five/london-meals).
On a brilliant summer’s day, London Fields, one of many Victorian-era public parks, can turn into a bucolic version of the Riviera.
Victoria Park is another East London alfresco rendezvous for sun worshippers—as well as a reminder of the gentle traditions of English landscaping.
If you go looking for a market, be sure to check which days it appears—the **[Broadway flea market](http://www.broadwaymarket.co.uk/)** happens only on Saturdays.

items.title: 9. Whitechapel Gallery
items.caption:
The original East End art space, the [**Whitechapel Gallery**](http://www.whitechapelgallery.org/) (pictured), has an excellent restaurant overseen by Gordon Ramsay disciple Angela Hartnett. The Whitechapel organizes bus and walking tours of some of the East End's 100 galleries and museums on the first Thursday of the month, when it's open until 9 p.m. (77-82 Whitechapel High St.; 20-7522-7888; entrées from $19).




**[The Frieze Foundation](http://www.friezefoundation.org/)**, which organizes the highly successful annual Frieze Art Fair (debuting in New York City this month, May 4–7), has commissioned Frieze Projects East—four new public art projects opening on June 25 as part of the 2012 London festival.
The elusive and now-famous graffiti artist Banksy has inspired much spontaneous street art, like these murals near Commercial Street.
For art that you can buy and take away, there is the **[Nelly Duff](http://www.nellyduff.com/) **gallery on Columbia Road, with an eclectic selection and a hip curator.
Street art is sometimes subtly political, a creative riff on agitprop—like this cartoony creation with overtones of the work of R. Crumb.

items.title: 5. Victoria Miro Gallery
items.caption: The **[Victoria Miro Gallery](http://www.victoria-miro.com/)**, which opened in 2000, the same year as the White Cube, shows established and emerging artists: Turner Prize winners Chris Ofili and Grayson Perry; pioneering sculptor Conrad Shawcross (16 Wharf Rd.; 20-7336-8109).
items.credit: Grayson Perry, Courtesy Victoria Miro Gallery

items.caption: _Two Fried Eggs and a Kebab,_ by Sarah Lucas. Called the wildest of the Young British Artists, Lucas made her name with cheeky sexual metaphors.

_Cheap Magic Is Anticipated,_ by Ryan Gander, is a mixed-media piece at the **[Lisson Gallery](http://www.lissongallery.com/)**. Gander, who is disabled, works from a wheelchair. A critic has described his work as “lucid dreaming.”
items.credit: Courtesy Ryan Gander and Lisson Gallery

items.caption: A sculpture on a plinth, _National Geographic_ is by Rebecca Warren, who was nominated for the prestigious Turner Prize in 2006.

items.caption:
